body: Want review from @ellisonbg, @jdfreder

> therefore the metadata is lost at that point.

Should investigate this. it shouldn't be lost at that point IIRC.

>  Indeed the higlight filter interface
> only sees the cell content,

Nothing prevents you from changing this interface.  You could change the templates so they pass the `cell` in instead of `cell.input`.  Then you could have all of the metadata associated with the cell, including any language metadata **if it existed**.  

Unfortunately, a quick test shows that there isn't any useful metadata regarding the language magics in our current nb format (v3)

``` json
{"cells": [
    {
     "cell_type": "code",
     "collapsed": false,
     "input": [
      "%%bash\n",
      "#hello\n",
      "print(test)\n"
     ],
     "language": "python",
     "metadata": {},
     "outputs": [
      {
       "output_type": "stream",
       "stream": "stderr",
       "text": [
        "bash: line 2: syntax error near unexpected token `test'\n",
        "bash: line 2: `print(test)'\n"
       ]
      }
     ],
     "prompt_number": 3
    },
    {
     "cell_type": "code",
     "collapsed": false,
     "input": [
      "%%bash\n",
      "#test"
     ],
     "language": "python",
     "metadata": {},
     "outputs": []
    }
   ]}
```

Note: This did highlight correctly in the browser.

@jdfreder 

> Nothing prevents you from changing this interface. You could change the templates so they pass the cell in >instead of cell.input. Then you could have all of the metadata associated with the cell, including any language >metadata if it existed.
> 
> Unfortunately, a quick test shows that there isn't any useful metadata regarding the language magics in our >current nb format (v3)
> [...]

Yes you are right, we could change the interface and modify the calls to `highlight2xxx` in the templates.
I think it would be a good idea.

Now, thinking a bit more about the magic languages used in cell, I realized we could have cells with different
languages in the same cell, for instance:

```
# This is python
print("hello python")

# This is bash
% bash echo "bash"

# This is R
% R print("R")
```

In that case, it's not clear how to tag the cell metadata.

Admitedly, my PR only handles cells which are fully written in a single magic language (such as %%R ).
Nevertheless, ideally we could extend nbviewer so multiple language cells are correctly highlighted.
With this extension in mind, I think it's better to delegate the highlighting heuristic to the highlight filter.

What do you think ?

Finally, I refactored it as you two were suggesting:
- A preprocessor to tag cells using magic extension languages
- The highlight filter now gets the full cell object, and highlights the cell depending on the metadata

The advantages of the preprocessor, is that it is configurable (now the languages re are in a configurable Dict as suggested) and it can be disabled easily.

I changed the detection heuristic to be more strict, now a cell is tagged only if the '%%language' is found on the first line of the cell. This is to avoid false positives such as:

``` python
print("""
%%R
""")
```

Please could you review the new version ?

Thanks,

Pablo

> @jdfreder has probably work more on that than me, and woud be of better advice, but what do you think of
> 
> {{ cell.input | highlight2html(metadata=cell.metadata) }}
> 
> That would allow to use the filter to highlight other things I guess.

I agree, since the cell.input is passed into the filter already, because of the Jinja filter syntax.

> Admitedly, my PR only handles cells which are fully written in a single magic language (such as %%R ).
> Nevertheless, ideally we could extend nbviewer so multiple language cells are correctly highlighted.
> With this extension in mind, I think it's better to delegate the highlighting heuristic to the highlight filter.
> 
> What do you think ?

If you want to support multiple languages in a single cell, you'll probably need to [write a custom Pygments lexer](http://pygments.org/docs/lexerdevelopment/) that can switch between built-in lexers depending on the contents.  Now, I'm not suggesting you do this, I'm just telling you that this is probably the easiest way to accomplish this.  

Continuing one that point, if you had the custom lexer, you wouldn't need to pass the metadata into the highlight filter anymore.  Of course, I think having the language information in the metadata is useful because it's more power to the templates.  I wouldn't suggest removing it, but you would probably need to set the language as "mixed" or "unknown" if the preprocessor detected multiple languages.

> If you want to support multiple languages in a single cell, you'll probably need to write a custom Pygments lexer that can switch between built-in lexers depending on the contents. Now, I'm not suggesting you do 
> this, I'm just telling you that this is probably the easiest way to accomplish this. [...] I wouldn't suggest removing it, but you would probably need to set the language as "mixed" or "unknown" if the preprocessor detected multiple languages.

I fully agree. But that's a fair amount of work, let's keep it for later :)

 Thanks for your review.

Looks goo to me then. 
When do we switch nbviewer to IPython dev :-) 

Waiting 24h and merging if no objections.

> Looks goo to me then. 

Ditto
Fixed. Thanks for your comments :)
re-looks good to me.
Done. Thanks @damianavila!
Thanks to you! :-)

No, multiple commits are fine. We keep rebase for conflict and/or obviously too long history for one small change.

Min sometime use it to hide some of the shamefull mistakes he does like forgetting to erase a debug print statement.

Envoyé de mon iPhone

Le 17 sept. 2013 à 17:21, Pablo de Oliveira Castro notifications@github.com a écrit :

> Removed obsolete import in highlight and rebased on master.
> 
> @Carreau, should I rebase with a single clean commit message before the merge or is this fine ?
> 
> Thanks,
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
This needs a rebase now.
@minrk, rebased with no conflicts. Tests pass.

Can I ask why this information is computed in a preprocessor, and then relayed to the highlight filter? It seems the highlight filter has everything it needs to actually compute this itself. Why is this information not simply part of highlighting 'ipython' syntax?

Plus, we should only be enabling preprocessors in individual exporters' default_config that are generally off by default, whereas it seems like this one should be _on_ by default, and thus in _default_preprocessors (assuming we don't get rid of the preprocessor altogether).

@minrk:

> Can I ask why this information is computed in a preprocessor, and then relayed to the highlight filter? It >seems the highlight filter has everything it needs to actually compute this itself. Why is this information not >simply part of highlighting 'ipython' syntax?

The initial pull request (009a294) computed the information directly in the highlight filter.
@jdfreder and @Carreau suggested to rewrite it using a preprocessor, I suppose for:
- modularity reasons 
- so that it can be disabled 
- so that new languages can be added by configuration

I'm willing to revert to its previous behavior, but I really would like that we reach a consensus before redoing the work.

> Plus, we should only be enabling preprocessors in individual exporters' default_config that are generally off >by default, whereas it seems like this one should be on by default, and thus in _default_preprocessors
> (assuming we don't get rid of the preprocessor altogether).

Not sure to understand what you mean here.

Thanks,

Pablo

It's easier to update the detecting of the language afterward and make the detecting/highlight decoupled.

The first implementation was putting all the logics in the highlight filter.

Envoyé de mon iPhone

Le 18 sept. 2013 à 20:54, Min RK notifications@github.com a écrit :

> Can I ask why this information is computed in a preprocessor, and then relayed to the highlight filter? It seems the highlight filter has everything it needs to actually compute this itself. Why is this information not simply part of highlighting 'ipython' syntax?
> 
> Plus, we should only be enabling preprocessors in individual exporters' default_config that are generally off by default, whereas it seems like this one should be on by default, and thus in _default_preprocessors (assuming we don't get rid of the preprocessor altogether).
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

> Not sure [I] understand what you mean here.

There is a list of preprocessors that are enabled by default. They are a class attribute on TemplateExporter, called `preprocessors`.  The `default_config` property on subclasses is for enabling preprocessors that are _not_ on by default. Since this PR enables the preprocessor pretty much everywhere, that suggests that `default_config` is not actually the right way to do it, rather just adding it to TemplateExporter.preprocessors instead.

**EDIT** fixed `default_preprocessors` -> `preprocessors` mixup.

@minrk: Thanks for your explanation! Still I have a couple of questions:

1) I do not see a `TemplateExporter.default_preprocessors`
There is a `Exporter.default_preprocessors`, but from my understanding it does not enable preprocessors, it just makes them available. You still have to manually turn them on using `default_config`.

2) I'm not sure that  MagicsHighlightPreprocessor should be enabled in the markdown or rst exporters, since the highlight filter is not applied on them.

Thanks,

Pablo

I updated my comment to point to `preprocessors` instead of `default_preprocessors`.  Now I think the default_config approach is okay, if suboptimal. Hopefully some day we will figure out how to do away with Exporter.default_config altogether, because it is very problematic.

I think this PR is reasonable to merge, given the current state of nbconvert.
@minrk: fixed style :)
